standard_metadata.standard_description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Model with one-step equations and solve

question.content: Eva and Jamir like to bake cookies. Eva baked $24$ chocolate chip cookies, and Jamir baked $p$ peanut butter cookies. Together they baked a total of $56$ cookies.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**    **How many cookies did Jamir bake?**

hints.content: Eva baked $\blueD{24}$ cookies, and Jamir baked an unknown number of cookies, which we're calling $\greenD{p}$. All together, they baked $\maroonD{56}$ cookies.
We can represent Eva and Jamir's cookies as a sum:   $\blueD{24} + \greenD{p}$  We know that together they baked $\maroonD{56}$ cookies.

The following equation matches this situation:  $\blueD{24} + \greenD{p} = \maroonD{56}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:  $\greenD{p} + \blueD{24} = \maroonD{56}$ or  $\maroonD{56} - \greenD{p} = \blueD{24}$ or $\maroonD{56} - \blueD{24} = \greenD{p}$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{p}$.  Subtract $\blueD{24}$ from both sides of the equation to get $\greenD{p}$ by itself:  $\begin{align} \blueD{24} -\blueD{24} + \greenD{p} &= \maroonD{56}-\blueD{24}  \\ \\  \greenD{p} &=\greenD{32} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $\blueD{24} + \greenD{p} = \maroonD{56}$  Jamir baked $\greenD{32}$ cookies.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Kim and Stacy like to make necklaces. Kim has made $25$  necklaces, and Stacy has made $t$ necklaces. They have made a total of $57$ necklaces all together.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**    **How many necklaces did Stacy make?**

hints.content: Kim has made $\blueD{25}$ necklaces, and Stacy has made an unknown amount of necklaces, which we're calling $\greenD{t}$. All together, they have made $\maroonD{57}$ necklaces.
We can represent the amount of necklaces that Kim and Stacy made as a sum:  $\blueD{25} + \greenD{t}$  We know that together they made $\maroonD{57}$ necklaces.

The following equation matches this situation:  $\blueD{25} + \greenD{t} = \maroonD{57}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:  $\greenD{t} + \blueD{25} = \maroonD{57}$ or $\maroonD{57} - \greenD{t} = \blueD{25}$ or $\maroonD{57} - \blueD{25} =\greenD{t}$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{t}$.  Subtract $\blueD{25}$ from both sides of the equation to get $\greenD{t}$ by itself:  $\begin{align} \blueD{25} -\blueD{25} + \greenD{t} &= \maroonD{57}-\blueD{25}  \\ \\  \greenD{t} &=\greenD{32} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $\blueD{25} + \greenD{t} = \maroonD{57}$  Stacy made $\greenD{32}$ necklaces.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Molly and Torry like to eat ice cream sandwiches. In one week, Molly ate $5$ ice cream sandwiches, and Torry ate $n$ ice cream sandwiches. They ate a total of $12$ ice cream sandwiches all together.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**    **How many ice cream sandwiches did Torry eat?**

images.alt: Image of an ice cream sandwich.

hints.content: Molly ate $\blueD{5}$ ice cream sandwiches, and Torry ate an unknown number of ice cream sandwiches, which we're calling $\greenD{n}$. All together, they ate $\maroonD{12}$ ice cream sandwiches.
We can represent Molly and Torry's ice cream sandwiches as a sum:   $\blueD{5} + \greenD{n}$  We know that together they ate $\maroonD{12}$ ice cream sandwiches in one week.

The following equation matches this situation:  $\blueD{5} + \greenD{n} = \maroonD{12}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:  $\greenD{n} + \blueD{5} = \maroonD{12}$ or $\maroonD{12} - \greenD{n} = \blueD{5}$ or $\maroonD{12} - \blueD{5} = \greenD{n}$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{n}$.  Subtract $\blueD{5}$ from both sides of the equation to get $\greenD{n}$ by itself:  $\begin{align} \blueD{5} -\blueD{5} + \greenD{n} &= \maroonD{12}-\blueD{5}  \\ \\  \greenD{n} &=\greenD{7} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $\blueD{5} + \greenD{n} = \maroonD{12}$  Torry ate  $\greenD{7}$ ice cream sandwiches.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Juan and Rob are selling cookie dough for a school fundraiser. Juan has $t$ cookie dough orders, and Rob has $40$ cookie dough orders. They have a total of $75$ cookie dough orders all together.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**    **How many cookie dough orders does Juan have?**

hints.content: Juan has an unknown number of cookie dough orders, which we're calling $\blueD{t}$, and Rob has $\greenD{40}$ cookie dough orders. All together, they have $\maroonD{75}$ cookie dough orders.
We can represent Juan and Rob's cookie dough orders as a sum:  $\blueD{t} + \greenD{40}$  We know that together they have $\maroonD{75}$ cookie dough orders.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\blueD{t} + \greenD{40} = \maroonD{75}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:   $\greenD{40} + \blueD{t} = \maroonD{75}$ or  $\maroonD{75} = \greenD{40} =\blueD{t}$, or  $\maroonD{75} - \blueD{t} = \greenD{40}$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{t}$.  Subtract $\greenD{40}$ from both sides of the equation to get $\greenD{t}$ by itself:  $\begin{align} \blueD t +\greenD{40} -\greenD{40}  &= \maroonD{75}-\greenD{40}  \\ \\  \blueD{t} &=\blueD{35} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $\blueD{t} + \greenD{40} = \maroonD{75}$  Juan has  $\blueD{35}$ cookie dough orders.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Carl is on the school track team. To prepare for an upcoming race, he plans to run $217$ miles total over the next $31$ days.   **Write an equation to determine how many miles, $m$, he needs to run per day, assuming he runs the same amount each day.**    **How many miles does Carl need to run each day?**

hints.content: Carl will run an unknown number of miles, $\blueD{m}$, per day.  We know he plans to run $\greenD{217}$ miles total over $\maroonD{31}$ days.
To figure out how many miles Carl will run per day, we need to divide the total miles by the number of days.

We can find out how many miles Carl will run per day by solving this equation:   $\blueD{m}=\dfrac{\greenD{217}}{\maroonD{31}}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:  $\maroonD{31}{\blueD{m}}=\greenD{217}$ or $\dfrac{\greenD{217}}{\blueD{m} }=\maroonD{31}$.

Now we can solve for $\blueD{m}$.   Since $\blueD m$ is already by itself, we can solve by dividing $\dfrac{\greenD{217}}{\maroonD{31} }$.     $\begin{align} \blueD m  &=  \dfrac{\greenD{217}}{\maroonD{31} } \\ \\ \blueD{m} &=\blueD{7} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $\blueD m  =  \dfrac{\greenD{217}}{\maroonD{31}}$  Carl needs to run $\blueD{7}$ miles each day.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Noah is making grilled cheese sandwiches for friends. He has  $24$ ounces of cheese. He plans to split the cheese evenly between $6$ sandwiches.   **Write an equation to determine how many ounces of cheese, $c$, Noah can use on each sandwich.**    **How many ounces of cheese can Noah use on each sandwich?**

hints.content: Noah will use an unknown number of ounces of cheese, $\blueD{c}$, on each sandwich.  We know he has  $\greenD{24}$ ounces of cheese to use on $\maroonD{6}$ sandwiches.

We can find out how many ounces of cheese Noah can use on each sandwich, by finding the quotient:   $\blueD{c}=\dfrac{\greenD{24}}{\maroonD{6}}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:  $\dfrac{\greenD{24}}{\blueD{c} }=\maroonD{6}$ or $\maroonD{6}{\blueD{c}}=\greenD{24}$.

Now we can solve for $\blueD{c}$.   Since $\blueD c$ is already by itself, we can solve by dividing $\dfrac{\greenD{24}}{\maroonD{6} }$.     $\begin{align} \blueD c  &=  \dfrac{\greenD{24}}{\maroonD{6} } \\ \\ \blueD{c} &=\blueD{4} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  ${c}=\dfrac{{24}}{6}$  Noah can use  $4$ ounces of cheese on each sandwich.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Jayda takes her dog Rolo to obedience training once each week. Jayda bought a box of $96$ dog treats and split them evenly into $b$ bags. Each bag contains $16$ treats.  **Write an equation to describe this situation.**     **How many bags of dog treats does Jayda have?**

hints.content: Jayda started with $\blueD{96}$ dog treats.   She splits them into  $\greenD{b}$ bags, with  $\maroonD{16}$ treats in each bag.

We can find out how many bags of dog treats Jayda has by finding the quotient:   $\greenD{b}=\dfrac{\blueD{96}}{\maroonD{16}}$   Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:   $\dfrac{\blueD{96}}{\greenD{b} }=\maroonD{16}$ or $\maroonD{16}{\greenD{b}}=\blueD{96}$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{b}$.   Since $\greenD b$ is already by itself, we can solve by dividing $\dfrac{\blueD{96}}{\maroonD{16} }$.     $\begin{align} \greenD b  &=  \dfrac{\blueD{96}}{\maroonD{16} } \\ \\ \greenD b &=\greenD{6} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $ b  =  \dfrac{{96}}{{16}}$  Jayda has $6$ bags of dog treats.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Mu is walking laps to raise money for charity. For each lap she walks, her sponsors will donate $\$7$. Mu has walked $l$ laps and raised a total of $\$105$.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**    **How many laps has Mu walked?**

hints.content: Mu has raised a total of  $\blueD{\$105}$.   Her sponsors will donate $\greenD{\$7}$ for each lap, with  $\maroonD{l}$ laps walked.

We can find out how many laps Mu has walked by finding the quotient:   $\greenD{l}=\dfrac{\blueD{105}}{\maroonD{7}}$   Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include: $\dfrac{\blueD{105}}{\greenD{l} }=\maroonD{7}$ or $\maroonD{7}{\greenD{l}}=\blueD{105}$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{l}$.   Since $\greenD l$ is already by itself, we can solve by dividing $\dfrac{\blueD{105}}{\maroonD{7}}$.     $\begin{align} \greenD l  &=  \dfrac{\blueD{105}}{\maroonD{7} } \\ \\ \greenD l &=\greenD{15} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $ l  =  \dfrac{105}{{7} }$  Mu has walked $15$ laps.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Amia went to a flower farm and picked $f$ flowers. When she got home, she put the flowers in $4$ vases, with $22$ flowers in each vase.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**    **How many flowers did Amia pick at the farm?**

hints.content: Amia picked a total of  $\blueD{f}$ flowers at the farm.  She put the flowers in  $\greenD{4}$ vases with $\maroonD{22}$ flowers in each vase.

We can find out how many total flowers Amia picked by finding the quotient:   $\greenD{4}=\dfrac{\blueD{f}}{\maroonD{22}}$   Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include: $\dfrac{\blueD{f}}{\greenD{4} }=\maroonD{22}$ or $\maroonD{22} \cdot {\greenD{4}}=\blueD{f}$.

Now we can solve for $\blueD{f}$.   Multiply both sides by $\maroonD{22}$ to get $\blueD f$ by itself.    $\begin{align} \greenD{4\cdot \maroonD {22} }&=\dfrac{\blueD{f}}{\maroonD{22}} \cdot \maroonD{22} \\ \\ \blueD f &=\blueD{88} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $4=\dfrac{f}{22}$  Amia picked $88$ flowers at the farm.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: The Brown family has many pairs of athletic shoes. They counted $p$ pairs all together. They decided to give away $6$ pairs, because they had outgrown them. After giving $6$ pairs away, the  Brown family still has $11$ pairs of athletic shoes remaining.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**    **How many pairs of shoes did the Brown family start with?**

hints.content: The Brown family had $\blueD{p}$ pairs of athletic shoes. They gave away $\greenD{6}$ pairs. After giving some shoes away, they have $\maroonD{11}$ pairs remaining.
We can represent the number of pairs of athletic shoes that the Brown family  has remaining as a difference:  $\blueD{p} - \greenD{6}$  We know that they have $\maroonD{11}$ pairs of shoes remaining.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\blueD{p} - \greenD{6} = \maroonD{11}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:  $\maroonD{11} = \blueD{p} - \greenD{6}$ or $\blueD p = \greenD6 + \maroonD{11}$.

Now we can solve for $\blueD{p}$.  Add $\greenD{6}$ to both sides of the equation to get $\blueD{p}$ by itself:  $\begin{align} \blueD p -\greenD{6} +\greenD{6}  &= \maroonD{11}+\greenD{6}  \\ \\  \blueD{p} &=\blueD{17} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $p - 6 = 11$  The Brown family started out with  $17$ pairs of shoes.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Liang bought a basket of apples to make pies for her friends. The basket of apples weighed $p$ pounds. Before she had time to make the pies, she ate $3$ pounds of apples. There are $17$ pounds of apples left to make pies.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**    **What was the total weight of the basket of apples?**

hints.content: The weight of the basket of apples was  $\blueD{p}$ pounds. Liang ate $\greenD{3}$ pounds of apples, and there were $\maroonD{17}$ pounds left to make pies.
We can represent the total number of pounds of apples left to make pies as a difference:  $\blueD{p} - \greenD{3}$  We know there were $\maroonD{17}$ pounds of apples left to make pies.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\blueD{p} - \greenD{3} = \maroonD{17}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:  $\maroonD{17} = \blueD{p} - \greenD{3}$ or $\blueD p =\maroonD{17} + \greenD3$.

Now we can solve for $\blueD{p}$.  Add $\greenD{3}$ to both sides of the equation to get $\blueD{p}$ by itself:  $\begin{align} \blueD p -\greenD{3} +\greenD{3}  &= \maroonD{17}+\greenD{3}  \\ \\  \blueD{p} &=\blueD{20} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $p-3=17$  The total weight of the basket of apples was $20$ pounds.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Jolie earned $\$205$ for babysitting in one month. She spent $d$ dollars going to a water park with some friends. After going to the water park, Jolie had $\$160$ remaining.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**     **How many dollars did Jolie spend at the water park?**

images.alt: Image of an unknown dollar bill.

hints.content: Jolie earned $\blueD{$205}$ babysitting. She spent an unknown number of dollars, which we're calling $\green{d}$ dollars at the water park. She had $\maroonD{$160}$ remaining after going to the water park.
We can represent the amount of money that Jolie has left after visiting the water park as a difference:  $\blueD{205} - \greenD{d}$  We know that she has $\maroonD{$160}$ remaining.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\blueD{205} - \greenD{d} = \maroonD{160}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include: $\maroonD{160} = \blueD{205} - \greenD{d}$ or $\blueD{205} = \greenD d + \maroonD{160}$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{d}$.  Add $\greenD{d}$ to both sides of the equation then subtract $\maroonD{160}$ from both sides:  $\begin{align} \blueD{205} -\greenD{d} +\greenD{d}  &= \maroonD{160}+\greenD{d}  \\ \blueD{205}  &= \maroonD{160}+\greenD{d}  \\ \blueD{205} -\maroonD{160}  &= \maroonD{160}-\maroonD{160}+\greenD{d}  \\ \greenD{45} &=\greenD d  \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $205-d=160$  Jolie spent  $\$45$ at the water park.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Eloise scored a total of  $268$ points during the basketball season. Of her total points, $l$ points came from left-handed shots. She scored $225$ points with right-handed shots.  **Write an equation to describe this situation.**     **How many points did Eloise score with left-handed shots?**

hints.content: Eloise scored $\blueD{225}$ points with right-handed shots. She scored an unknown number of points, which we're calling $\green{l}$, that were left-handed. Eloise scored a total of  $\maroonD{268}$ points during the season.
We can represent the number of points that Eloise scored left-handed, $\greenD l$, as a difference:  $\maroonD{268} - \blueD{225}$

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\maroonD{268} -\blueD{225} = \greenD{l} $  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:   $\greenD l +\blueD{225} = \maroonD{268} $ or $\maroonD{268} - \greenD l = \blueD{225}$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{l}$.  Since $\greenD{l}$ is already by itself, we can solve by subtracting.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{268} -\blueD{225}  &= \greenD{l}  \\ \greenD{43}  &=\greenD{l}   \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $268-225=l$  Eloise scored $43$ points with left-handed shots.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: An ice cream truck started the day with $45$ ice cream sandwiches. During a stop at a busy park they sold $s$ ice cream sandwiches. After the stop, the truck had $21$ ice cream sandwiches remaining.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**     **How many ice cream sandwiches did the truck sell at the park?**

images.alt: Image of an ice cream sandwich.

hints.content: The truck started with a total of  $\maroonD{45}$ ice cream sandwiches. They sold an unknown number of sandwiches at the park, which we're calling $\green{s}$. The truck had $\blueD{21}$ ice cream sandwiches remaining after the stop at the park.
We can represent the number of ice cream sandwiches the truck has remaining  as a difference:  $\maroonD{45} - \greenD{s}$  We know the truck has  $\blueD{21}$ ice cream sandwiches remaining.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\maroonD{45} -\greenD{s} = \blueD{21} $  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:  $\maroonD{45} - \blueD{21} = \greenD{s}$ or $\blueD{21} + \greenD s = \maroonD{45} $.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{s}$.  Add $\greenD{s}$ to both sides of the equation then subtract $\blueD{21}$ from both sides:  $\begin{align} \maroonD{45} -\greenD{s} +\greenD{s}  &= \blueD{21}+\greenD{s}  \\ \maroonD{45}  &= \blueD{21}+\greenD{s}  \\ \maroonD{45} -\blueD{21}  &= \blueD{21}-\blueD{21}+\greenD{s}  \\ \greenD{24} &=\greenD s  \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $45-s=21$  The ice cream truck sold $24$ ice cream sandwiches at the park.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: A group of neighbors is holding an end of summer block party. They buy  $p$ packs of hot dogs, with $8$ hot dogs in each pack. All together, they have $56$ hot dogs for the party.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**     **How many packs of hot dogs did the neighbors buy?**

hints.content: There are $\blueD8$ hot dogs in each pack. We are calling the number of packs of hot dogs $\green{p}$ . There were a total of $\maroonD{56}$ hot dogs at the party.
We can represent the total number of hot dogs at the party as a product:  $\blueD{8} \greenD{p}$  We know that there were a total of  $\maroonD{56}$ hot dogs at the party.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\blueD{8} \greenD{p} = \maroonD{56}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:   $\dfrac{\maroonD{56}}{\greenD p}=\blueD8$ or $\dfrac{\maroonD{56}}{\blueD 8}=\greenD p$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{p}$.  Divide both sides by $\blueD{8}$ to get $\greenD p$ by itself.   $\begin{align}\dfrac{ \blueD{8}\greenD{p}}{\blueD8} &=  \dfrac{\maroonD{56}}{\blueD8} \\\\ \greenD{p} &=\greenD 7  \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $8p=56$  The neighbors bought $7$ packs of hot dogs.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: At a party to celebrate a successful school play, the drama club bought $9$ large pizzas. Each pizza had $s$ slices. All together, there were $72$ slices of pizza for the club to share.  **Write an equation to describe this situation.**     **How many slices does each pizza have?**

hints.content: There are $\blueD9$ pizzas at the party. We are calling the number of slices in each pizza $\green{s}$. There were a total of $\maroonD{72}$ slices of pizza.
We can represent the total number of slices of pizza as a product:  $\blueD{9} \greenD{s}$  We know that there were a total of  $\maroonD{72}$ slices of pizza.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\blueD{9} \greenD{s} = \maroonD{72}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include: $\dfrac{\maroonD{72}}{\greenD s}=\blueD9$ or $\dfrac{\maroonD{72}}{\blueD 9}=\greenD s$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{s}$.  Divide both sides by $\blueD{9}$ to get $\greenD s$ by itself.   $\begin{align}\dfrac{ \blueD{9}\greenD{s}}{\blueD9} &=  \dfrac{\maroonD{72}}{\blueD9} \\\\ \greenD{s} &=\greenD 8  \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:   $9s = 72$  Each pizza has $8$ slices.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Gustave measured his pace and determined that for him, $s$ steps make up one mile. One day Gustave walked $6300$ steps, which was $3$ miles.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**     **How many steps are in one mile for Gustave?**

hints.content: Gustave walked $\maroonD{6300}$ steps, which was the same as  $\blueD3$ miles. We are calling the number of steps in one mile for Gustave $\green{s}$.
We can represent the total number of steps Gustave took on his walk as a product:  $\blueD{3} \greenD{s}$  We know that there were a total of  $\maroonD{6300}$ steps.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\blueD{3} \greenD{s} = \maroonD{6300}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include: $\dfrac{\maroonD{6300}}{\greenD s}=\blueD3$ or $\dfrac{\maroonD{6300}}{\blueD 3}=\greenD s$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{s}$.  Divide both sides by $\blueD{3}$ to get $\greenD s$ by itself.   $\begin{align}\dfrac{ \blueD{3}\cdot\greenD{s}}{\blueD3} &=  \dfrac{\maroonD{6300}}{\blueD3} \\\\ \greenD{s} &=\greenD{2100}  \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:   $3s=6300$  There are $2100$ steps in one mile for Gustave.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: Kojo wants to be an author. To improve his writing skills, every day after school he writes $3$ pages of a story he is working on. Kojo has been writing his story for $d$ days. He has a total of $81$ pages completed.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**     **How many days has Kojo been writing his story?**

hints.content: Kojo writes $\blueD{3}$ pages each day. He has been writing for an unknown number of days, which we're calling $\green{d}$. He has written a total of  $\maroonD{81}$ pages.
We can represent the total number of pages that Kojo has written as a product:  $\blueD{3} \greenD{d}$  We know that he has written $\maroonD{81}$ pages.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\blueD{3}  \greenD{d} = \maroonD{81}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include: $\dfrac{\maroonD{81}}{\greenD d}=\blueD3$ or $\dfrac{\maroonD{81}}{\blueD 3}=\greenD d$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{d}$.  Divide both sides by $\blueD{3}$ to get $\greenD d$ by itself.   $\begin{align}\dfrac{ \blueD{3}\greenD{d}}{\blueD3} &=  \dfrac{\maroonD{81}}{\blueD3} \\\\ \greenD{d} &=\greenD{ 27}  \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $3d=81$  Kojo has been writing his story for $27$ days.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: At the Many Chips Cookie Company, they are serious about the number of chocolate chips in their cookies. They claim that each cookie has $c$ chips. If their claim is true, there will be $200$ chips in $10$ cookies.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**     **How many chips does the company claim are in each cookie?**

hints.content: There are $\blueD{10}$ cookies, with a total of $\maroonD{200}$ chips . Each cookie has an unknown number of chips, which we're calling $\green{c}$.
We can represent the total number of chips in the cookies as a product:  $\blueD{10}  \greenD{c}$  If the claims are true, there are a total of $\maroonD{200}$ chips.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\blueD{10}  \greenD{c} = \maroonD{200}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include: $\dfrac{\maroonD{200}}{\greenD c}=\blueD{10}$ or $\dfrac{\maroonD{200}}{\blueD {10}}=\greenD c$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{c}$.  Divide both sides by $\blueD{10}$ to get $\greenD c$ by itself.   $\begin{align}\dfrac{ \blueD{10}\greenD{c}}{\blueD{10}} &=  \dfrac{\maroonD{200}}{\blueD{10}} \\\\ \greenD{c} &=\greenD {20}  \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $10c = 200$   The company claims there are $20$ chips in each cookie.

item.problemType: NEW EXERCISE: Translate context + solve (20 items)

question.content: After Luca took his dogs for a walk, he gave them  $6$ dog treats. When Luca's dad got home from work, he gave the dogs $t$ more treats. All together that day, Luca's dogs got $10$ dog treats.   **Write an equation to describe this situation.**    **How many dog treats did Luca's dad give the dogs?**

hints.content: Luca gave his dogs $\blueD{6}$ dog treats. Luca's dad gave the dogs $\greenD{t}$ more treats. All together, the dogs had $\maroonD{10}$ dog treats.
We can represent the number of treats Luca's dogs ate as a sum:  $\blueD{6} + \greenD{t}$  We know that the dogs got $\maroonD{10}$ treats all together.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:  $\blueD{6} + \greenD{t} = \maroonD{10}$  Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include:  $\greenD{t} + \blueD{6} = \maroonD{10}$ or $\maroonD{10} - \greenD{t} = \blueD{6}$, or  $\maroonD{10} - \blueD{6} =\greenD{t}$.

Now we can solve for $\greenD{t}$.  Subtract $\blueD{6}$ from both sides of the equation to get $\greenD{t}$ by itself:  $\begin{align} \blueD 6 -\blueD6+\greenD{t}   &= \maroonD{10}-\greenD{6}  \\ \\  \greenD{t} &=\greenD{4} \end{align}$
The following equation matches this situation:  $6+t=10$  Luca's dad gave the dogs $4$ treats.
